name: eschrichtius-robustus
definition: The gray whale is a baleen whale that migrates between feeding and breeding grounds yearly.
description:
The gray whale is a giant of the ocean, mottled light to dark gray in color and encrusted with barnacles and whale lice.

It has no dorsal fin, instead having a series of bumps on the last third of its back along a dorsal ridge.

It has two deep grooves on its throat, which enable its mouth to expand when it feeds.

The baleen, which it uses to filter food, is creamy-white.

Females are usually larger than males and otherwise look the same as males.

There are two separate geographic distributions in the North Pacific Ocean of these whales.

The Eastern North Pacific stock, which inhabits North America’s west coast, and the Korean stock of the Western North Pacific, which occurs along the coasts of eastern Asia.

Gray whales are opportunistic feeders and their diet include a wide range of crustaceans.

They eat shrimp and amphipods, as well as herring eggs, polychaete worms, and various kinds of larvae.

Killer whales, the large sharks, and humans are the gray whales' only natural predators.

Skin parasites - including barnacles and whale lice, attach themselves to the head area, back, and blowhole area also.

Gray whales are promiscuous with complex breeding behavior.

After a gestation period of 13 to 14 months, a female bears a single calf, which she nurses until it is the age of 6 to 7 months.

Females are fiercely defensive of the young against potential predators.

The offspring inherit the feeding grounds of their mothers and are often seen in them a year after they become independent.

Gray whales achieve sexual maturity from 5 to 11 years of age.

Gray whales feed mainly during the long daylight hours of the summer months and often feed near to the shore.

They live in small groups, though sometimes form large pods, but don’t stay in the same group for all of their life.

Gray whales exhibit the behavior of spyhopping - lifting their heads right out of the water, exposing their entire rostrum for some minutes.

They do this while looking out for predators or other whales.

They also breach, which is understood to be a form of communication, a form of play, and an attempt at removing skin parasites.

Breaching is jumping up into the air then splash down onto their back or side.

Gray whales make the furthest migration known by any mammal.

Each spring and autumn they go from their summer feeding waters in the Arctic to the warm equatorial lagoons where the females give birth.

related.definition: The blue whale  is a marine mammal belonging to the baleen whale parvorder, Mysticeti.
The killer whale or orca  is a toothed whale belonging to the oceanic dolphin family, of which it is the largest member.
The beluga whale   is an Arctic and sub-Arctic cetacean.
The narwhal is a medium-sized toothed whale that possesses a large tusk from a protruding canine tooth.
The bowhead whale  is a species of baleen whale belonging to the family Balaenidae and the only living representative of the genus Balaena.
